title: Switching between different base units

content.html: Something went wrong, you should checkout https://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_testsuite_dev/946/

content.raw: I'd like @ngoldbaum in particular to look at the changes I made in this file.
content.html: I'd like Nathan Goldbaum in particular to look at the changes I made in this file.

content.raw: Why is this error being raised unconditionally? What is unit_system == ds? Is that different from unit_system == 'code' or is this a typo?
content.html: Why is this error being raised unconditionally? What is unit_system == ds? Is that different from unit_system == 'code' or is this a typo?

content.raw:
First, I shouldn't have `"unit_system" == ds` but `"unit_system" = ds`. 

The reason it throws an error for `"code"` is that we don't know which system of `"code"` units it wants. To get code units you have to do something like `in_base(ds)`.
content.html:
First, I shouldn't have "unit_system" == ds but "unit_system" = ds.

The reason it throws an error for "code" is that we don't know which system of "code" units it wants. To get code units you have to do something like in_base(ds).

content.raw:
Ok, I think the way it's phrased right now is a little bit confusing, especially since not everyone will necessarily refer to a dataset as `ds` in their scripts. What about:

```
raise RuntimeError(r'You must refer to a dataset instance to convert to a code unit system.'
                   r'Try again with "get_base_equivalent(unit_system=ds)".')
```
content.html:
Ok, I think the way it's phrased right now is a little bit confusing, especially since not everyone will necessarily refer to a dataset as ds in their scripts. What about:

raise RuntimeError(r'You must refer to a dataset instance to convert to a code unit system.'
                   r'Try again with "get_base_equivalent(unit_system=ds)".')

content.html: I think that the chombo answer test failure is because the units changed from cgs base to Gauss? In that case we can regenerate, but not clear to me.

content.raw:
It looks like it's only the `GridValuesTest` for that field that's failing, but the projected values tests are passing.

https://tests.yt-project.org/job/py27_answer_chombo/900/console

(search for FAIL)

It looks like the plot window answer tests are also failing. Unfortunately the way we have the tests set up makes it kind of difficult to get the comparison images matplotlib spits out when these tests fail, so it might be easiest to try to reproduce these failures locally.
content.html:
It looks like it's only the GridValuesTest for that field that's failing, but the projected values tests are passing.

https://tests.yt-project.org/job/py27_answer_chombo/900/console

(search for FAIL)

It looks like the plot window answer tests are also failing. Unfortunately the way we have the tests set up makes it kind of difficult to get the comparison images matplotlib spits out when these tests fail, so it might be easiest to try to reproduce these failures locally.

content.raw: However, the different values for the `GridValuesTest` appears to be some kind of hash or something, which I don't understand. It's not clear to me what changed? I usually see differences in comparisons between NumPy arrays instead when we see an answer test fail.
content.html: However, the different values for the GridValuesTest appears to be some kind of hash or something, which I don't understand. It's not clear to me what changed? I usually see differences in comparisons between NumPy arrays instead when we see an answer test fail.

content.raw:
The `GridValuesTest` doesn't directly store the actual grid values (since that might be very large). Instead, it stores the md5 hashes of the grid values:

https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/81762aa466f368a730c369e7841f7234a06579b2/yt/utilities/answer_testing/framework.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#framework.py-541

So the test failure is saying that the grid values changed. The change might be small (i.e. floating point fuzz) - the only way to check is to redo the test and directly compare the grid values for the failing field.
content.html:
The GridValuesTest doesn't directly store the actual grid values (since that might be very large). Instead, it stores the md5 hashes of the grid values:

https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/81762aa466f368a730c369e7841f7234a06579b2/yt/utilities/answer_testing/framework.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#framework.py-541

So the test failure is saying that the grid values changed. The change might be small (i.e. floating point fuzz) - the only way to check is to redo the test and directly compare the grid values for the failing field.

content.raw: This is supposed to be a canary in a coal mine.  One possibility is that this causes more roundtrips of floating point ops, which would be problematic.
content.html: This is supposed to be a canary in a coal mine. One possibility is that this causes more roundtrips of floating point ops, which would be problematic.

The chombo failure appears to be almost certainly a precision-level difference, which does not surprise me, since the field definition has changed. Some pseudo-ish-code:

Before (when this was just an alias):

def _field_def(field, data):
    return data["magnetic_field_x"].copy()

After (when we possibly check for a unit conversion):

def _field_def(field, data):
    return data["magnetic_field_x"].in_units("gauss")

See https://bitbucket.org/jzuhone/yt-nonspatial/src/4b35d16f3256f3693ab84aff4637d9c8e6572bc6/yt/fields/magnetic_field.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#magnetic_field.py-134 and following

content.raw:
Before and after images for the failing `PlotWindow` answer tests:

Before: http://i.imgur.com/Llx6xRx.png

After: http://i.imgur.com/44get9G.png

If you diff these, we find out that the axes labels have moved slightly:

http://i.imgur.com/jAmiQsy.png

There is a (probably unnecessary) change in `PlotWindow`, but I've reverted it locally and it still doesn't change anything.
content.html:
Before and after images for the failing PlotWindow answer tests:

Before: http://i.imgur.com/Llx6xRx.png

After: http://i.imgur.com/44get9G.png

If you diff these, we find out that the axes labels have moved slightly:

http://i.imgur.com/jAmiQsy.png

There is a (probably unnecessary) change in PlotWindow, but I've reverted it locally and it still doesn't change anything.

content.raw:
If that's the case for all the failures I'd be ok with just generating new answers when this PR gets merged.

It would probably be best to wait on the new answer testing infrastructure where it will be easier to do that.

content.raw: Do you understand why the answers changed?
content.html: Do you understand why the answers changed?

content.raw:
Yes. 

1. In the case of the Chombo magnetic field, it's because we're not simply using an alias anymore but a derived field, and the last digit in some of the field values has changed.

2. In the case of the plot window tests, I've done a diff on the images and only change is that the axes labels are moved over by a couple of pixels. I'll admit I'm not sure why this is happening based on the changes in this PR, but the content of the images themselves has not changed so I figure this is also not an issue.
content.html:
Yes.

  1. In the case of the Chombo magnetic field, it's because we're not simply using an alias anymore but a derived field, and the last digit in some of the field values has changed.

  2. In the case of the plot window tests, I've done a diff on the images and only change is that the axes labels are moved over by a couple of pixels. I'll admit I'm not sure why this is happening based on the changes in this PR, but the content of the images themselves has not changed so I figure this is also not an issue.

content.raw: Fair enough, thanks for summarizing, and sorry for missing the discussion about about this.
content.html: Fair enough, thanks for summarizing, and sorry for missing the discussion about about this.

Perhaps you could point out here that this is equivalent do something like the following:

```
#!python

from yt.utilities.physical_constants import G
print G.in_base("mks")
```
content.html:
Perhaps you could point out here that this is equivalent do something like the following:

from yt.utilities.physical_constants import G
print G.in_base("mks")

content.raw:
@jzuhone, this looks really nice to me.  I don't have many comments on your implementation other than adding a couple docstrings and a couple other small things.  As for the `ytdata` frontend, it might work to add a `unit_system` keyword to `save_as_dataset`.  For custom unit systems, we would also need a way of saving the unit system as well.  I'd like to look into this after this PR is accepted.

Other than my comments and some minor merge conflicts that have popped up, I think this is good to go.
content.html:
John ZuHone, this looks really nice to me. I don't have many comments on your implementation other than adding a couple docstrings and a couple other small things. As for the ytdata frontend, it might work to add a unit_system keyword to save_as_dataset. For custom unit systems, we would also need a way of saving the unit system as well. I'd like to look into this after this PR is accepted.

Other than my comments and some minor merge conflicts that have popped up, I think this is good to go.

content.html: This is really terrific work, John ZuHone . A super welcome addition to the codebase.

description:
This PR adds the capability to switch between different base unit systems to yt. 

To understand this functionality, it's probably easiest to read the YTEP:

YTEP PR: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/ytep/pull-requests/58/adding-ytep-0028-for-different-unit/
Nice-looking version: http://www.jzuhone.com/ytep/YTEPs/YTEP-0028.html

Some caveats:

* I haven't decided what to do about the `ytdata` frontend--it serializes new datasets in CGS units, but @brittonsmith may have some ideas on how to incorporate this. 
* I haven't really touched the analysis modules--this will require more careful thinking about how they should or should not use this functionality. 

This is a big feature which touches a lot of the code, so I'm volunteering to not have this merged in until we have 5 approvals. 

I don't plan at the moment on adding any new functionality to this unless there are requests. Has some tests, needs docs. Will add the latter after we are sure the API is settled and before this goes in. 

Sorry for adding so many of you as reviewers, but wanted to get lots of eyes on this one, especially since it touches almost every frontend and every derived field. 

UPDATE: Docs have been written for this PR. We've determined that the answer test failures require new answers to be re-generated. After we review, this is good to go in.

UPDATE 2: Merged with recent changes and incorporated @ngoldbaum's suggestions. 

UPDATE 3: Merged with recent changes and incorporated @brittonsmith's suggestions.
